item.title: Pro-ject’s Colorful Turntables Please Your Eyes and Your Ears
item.description: So you’ve decided to hop on the vinyl trend. You need a turntable. Pro-ject’s candy hued Debut Carbon tables will appeal to both your eyes and your ears. Starting at around £265, they come in seven different color options. They come with a fully installed carbon fiber tonearm, but other than that they’re super pared [...]
item.dc:creator: Leslie Horn

item.title: What If The Sun Just Totally Disappeared?
item.description:
This is actually a pretty great thought experiment. At first it might seem kind of pointless to talk about what would happen if the sun vanished, but it doesn’t actually result in the immediate destruction of everything. Which is weird. Vsauce walks through a pretty nuanced description of how earth’s natural systems would slowly fail, [...]

item.title: Robots Save Easter After Negligent Bunny Makes A Mess Of Everything
item.description:
The Robotics and Perception Group in the Artificial Intelligence Lab at the University of Zurich is nailing it. Funded in 2012, they are studying the development of autonomous robots by making seasonal videos. Which is all anyone really wants. In the video a Parrot AR.Drone (they’re everywhere today) locates jellybean eggs that the Easter bunny [...]

item.title: Do You Still Print Stuff Out?
item.description: Yesterday I was printing a form and I realized it was the first time I had printed anything in months. For awhile I was the one who still had a paper copy of my bus ticket, Fandango confirmation, even driving directions. But yesterday I realized that my printer was covered in dust and stocked with [...]

item.title: Wooden Lamps Show The Light Within
item.description:
There’s something really meditative about these slotted lamps. They’re made out of wood from California cypress trees and the light inside is a constant current LED, but the sculptural elements come through more than the utility as a lamp. Designed by Paul Foeckler for Split Grain in LA, the lamps range from £495 to £1,285. [...]

item.title: DNA Is The Linux Of The Natural World
item.description:
We probably all vaguely assume that computers will overthrow us someday, which may be why it’s so unsettling to learn that computer code is evolving much like genetic code. By comparing bacterial genomes to Linux, researchers have found “survival of the fittest” acting in computer programming. Sergei Maslov of Brookhaven National Laboratory and Stony Brook [...]

item.title: Smell-O-Vision Might Actually Be Happening, But Who Even Knows Anymore
item.description: Eoesn’t it seem like being able to smell a TV show would be undesirable a lot of the time? Alex Trebek’s cologne would be wafting around your grandma’s all through Easter dinner and then your house would smell like blood after the Game of Thrones premier. But you gotta give the people what they want, [...]

item.title: DNA vs Razr: What’s Your Pick?
item.description:
The HTC Droid DNA and Motorola’s Droid RAZR HD/RAZR MAXX HD are all sweet handsets. The DNA of course has an edge in terms of screen and display while the RAZRs’ battery lives are unmatched in the Android ecosystem. item.title: This Modular Wine Wall Is Good Even When the Booze Is Bad
item.description:
Maybe you don’t know the first thing about wine except that you like it. Hell, maybe you make your oenological choices based on how cool the label is. Even if the wine is crap, you can still nail the presentation with STACT, a slick modular wine rack. Units start at about £85 and come in [...]

item.title: Roadrunner Supercomputer Goes Dark Today
item.description: The world’s fastest supercomputer isn’t the world’s fastest super computer anymore, so it’s getting turned off today. At Los Alamos National Laboratory, IBM’s Roadrunner is being replaced by a faster, cheaper and more energy efficient computer, Cielo. The £80 million Roadrunner supercomputer was the first to consistently compute a Petaflop, or a quadrillion mathematical calculations [...]

item.title: Drones Could Replace Eager Youths On Paper Routes
item.description:
Innovation in newspaper delivery techniques hasn’t really seemed like a priority in a while because of the whole death of print thing and whatever. But since drones categorically improve all situations, a local French postal service is turning paper routes into air routes. The postal service “La Poste Groupe” is using Auvergne, France as a [...]

item.title: What’s Your Earliest Memory of Using a Computer?
item.description:
We all use computers every day, but at some moment in each of our lives, there was that first meeting. A first interface, if you will. You might not remember the real first time you used a computer, but there’s got to be one shining gem of nostalgia that sticks out in your mind. What [...]

item.title: This Sculpture Makes a Highly Magnetic Material Move to Your Music
item.description:
Ferrofluids are liquids that become super magnetized when they’re in contact with a magnetic field. Ferrocious is a ferrofluid sculpture that uses the hyper-magnetic material respond to sound, like a high-tech musical lava lamp. Noises like your voice or the beat of a song will cause the copper colored electromagnet at the top of the [...]

item.title: DARPA’s Spleen-on-a-Chip Solves Sepsis
item.description:
Blood poisoning is the number one cause of death among critical care patients in the US, killing more than 200,000 people annually, And it’s estimated that there are over 30,000 sever cases of sepsis in the UK each year. However, a radical new treatment option could transform the way we treat sepsis and save thousands [...]

item.description:
Ikea’s furniture isn’t just cheap and easy to transport, it’s easy to hack too, with sites like Ikea Hackers showcasing some of the best modifications. item.description:
What with cloud storage becoming more and more affordable, chances are you’ve got a stack of old hard drives just laying around somewhere. At least one. item.title: These Awesome Floating Vases Are Practically Invisible
item.description:
An expensive, ornate vase can be as much of a centerpiece as the flowers that are in it. These floating vases designed by the Japanese group oodesign take things in the opposite direction by making them look like water ripples. The vases themselves are just discs of clear plastic, but the design idea behind them [...]

item.title: Scientists Scooped Out Virus Guts to Make a Sterile, Zombified Vaccine
item.description:
Vaccines beef up your immune system by giving it a little taste of a weak—but still alive—version of diseases. Now researchers over here in the UK have developed an alternative approach: rip out a virus’s insides and let your body crush its hollow husk. Not technically viruses but rather virus-like particles, the vaccine developed by [...]

item.title: If All Embassies Looked Like This There Wouldn’t Be Any Wars
item.description:
Believe it or not, this is the Dutch Embassy in Ethiopia. It doesn’t look like your average bureaucratic building, but perhaps more government agencies should take cues from not just its unusual aesthetic, but how the architects—Dick van Gameren and Bjarne Mastenbroek—drew influence from two different cultures. For example, the rough texture of the walls [...]

item.description:
